newsitem.title: USA: New Seattle football stadium clears first hurdle.
newsitem.headline: New Seattle football stadium clears first hurdle.

text.p: Billionaire Paul Allen savored his first victory Monday in his quest for a publicly funded football stadium in Seattle.

In a narrow voice vote, a state Senate panel approved -- and sent to the full Senate -- a package of specialty taxes to tear down Seattle's much-maligned Kingdome and build an open-air stadium in its place. Less than three weeks ago, the same committee rejected a similar package 18-3.

"We think the momentum has been building for the governor's latest package," said Bert Kolde, vice chairman of Allen's Football Northwest. Kolde said some lawmakers were persuaded to change their votes by a provision that calls for a statewide referendum.
"This entire plan requires a vote of the people. It will be placed on the ballot June 3," noted state Sen. Jim West during perfunctory committee debate.

The current version of a plan pushed by Democratic Gov. Gary Locke would pay for the new stadium with lottery scratch ticket games, a wholesale tax on sports logo-bearing items, and stadium admissions and parking taxes.
Allen, the multibillionaire co-founder of Microsoft Corp., would contribute $100 million toward the total project cost of $425 million.
Locke made personal appeals to senators of both parties in separate closed-door meetings Monday morning.

Allen's lobbyists indicated the billionaire is willing to be flexible on his looming stadium ultimatum. Early in March, Allen issued a strongly worded statement in which he threatened to walk away from his option to purchase the struggling Seahawks football team unless the legislature approved a new stadium by Thursday.
The full Senate could vote by Wednesday, but then the measure has to wind its way through the House.
"You never change the deadline until you get past it," was the way Allen's chief lobbyist Forrest "Bud" Coffey described the billionaire's attitude.
